items.title: [FEATURE] Document Python exceptions handling
items.body:
When an exception happens during a python callback execution, the callback is terminated and no changes are applied to the model. The user who doesn't have access to the stdout cannot see the exception and may get confused whether the response is slow or something went wrong.
It would be great if it was possible to handle exceptions that are happening on a document level, e.g. to display a popup message to the user.

I am suggesting to introduce a Document exception_callback. Something like this:
```python
document = curdoc()

error_div = Div(text="", visible=False)
document.add_root(error_div)

def exception_handler(error, traceback):
    error_div.text = str(error)
    error_div.visible = True

document.on_exception(exception_handler)
```

In my project (using Bokeh v.2.1.1) I have achieved this by monkey patching `@_needs_document_lock` decorator. I have added an `except` section in the `try` block:
```python
                try:
                    result = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
                    if inspect.isawaitable(result):
                        # Note that this must not be outside of the critical section.
                        # Otherwise, the async callback will be ran without document locking.
                        result = await result

                # -------- PATCH START ----------
                except Exception:
                    if hasattr(self._document, "exception_callback"):
                        exc_info = sys.exc_info()

                        def _on_exception():
                            self._document.exception_callback(exc_info[1], exc_info[2])

                        self._document.add_next_tick_callback(_on_exception)
                    raise
                # -------- PATCH FINISH ----------

                finally:
                    ...
```

items.body:
### FOLLOW THESE INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY

*ISSUES THAT DO NOT CONTAIN NECESSARY INFORMATION MAY BE CLOSED, IMMEDIATELY*

The issue tracker is NOT the place for general support. For questions and technical assistance, come join the [Bokeh  Project Discourse](https://discourse.bokeh.org).

For defects or deficiencies, please provide *ALL OF THE FOLLOWING*:

#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Issue is seen using bokeh versions 2.1.1 or 2.1.0. Note that behavior appears correct in earlier versions (tested with 2.0.2 and 2.0.0)
Issue seems to be specific to iPadOS/iOS (seen using iPadOS 13.6.1 and iOS 13.6.1). It can be seen using either Safari or Firefox browsers on those platforms.
The fact that it is only seen in recent versions of Bokeh makes me think this is more likely to be a bug in Bokeh (or at least an issue you may want to investigate) rather than an issue related to the browsers (e.g. the javascript engine). 

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
Observed behavior when saving an image using the SaveTool (i.e. the "disc" icon in the toolbar) is that the downloaded image is cropped and doesn't show the whole plot area. Expected behavior (seen using bokeh 2.0.2) is that downloaded image should show the entire plot.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
I encountered this during use of bokeh, but noticed that the issue is evident for plots shown in the bokeh documentation, which I think will be the easiest way for you to reproduce the issue.
e.g. https://docs.bokeh.org/en/2.1.1/docs/user_guide/quickstart.html#userguide-quickstart   shows the issue
whereas https://docs.bokeh.org/en/2.0.2/docs/user_guide/quickstart.html#userguide-quickstart shows the expected behavior.

See screenshots of bug behavior below. Note that selecting download results in a cropped image being saved.

items.title: [BUG] docs_json strings have improperly escaped quote characters
items.body:
bokeh: 2.1.1
python: 3.8.3
OS: windows

Code to reproduce (minimally edited code from https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/quickstart.html#userguide-quickstart)
```
from bokeh.plotting import figure, output_file, show
from bokeh.embed import components

# prepare some data
x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
y = [6, 7, 2, 4, 5]

# output to static HTML file
output_file("lines.html")

# create a new plot with a title and axis labels
p = figure(title="simple line example", x_axis_label='x', y_axis_label='y')

# add a line renderer with legend and line thickness
p.line(x, y, legend_label="Temp.", line_width=2)

# show the results
show(p)

# json-ify the results
script, div = components(p)
```

The resulting json data string from `show(p)` (the expected output):
```
{"f09d7e95-e4be-4b19-89b5-324c0b4aa714":{"roots":{"references":[{"attributes":{},"id":"1004","type":"DataRange1d"} ...
```

The resulting json data string from `components(p)` (improperly quoted):
```
'{"fb5578dd-c925-421f-a8bd-689a237db4d5":{"roots":{"references":[{"attributes":{"axis":{"id":"1016"}
```

I don't know if this was done intentionally since one value is embedded between <script> tags and the other is rendered directly as a string, but the `elements.script_for_render_items()` comments make it pretty explicit that `"` strings are to be avoided because of the impact they make on the size of generated files (which is how I detected this problem in the first place):
```
        # XXX: encodes &, <, > and ', but not ". This is because " is used a lot in JSON,
        # and encoding it would significantly increase size of generated files. Doing so
        # is safe, because " in strings was already encoded by JSON, and the semi-encoded
        # JSON string is included in JavaScript in single quotes.
```

items.title: [BUG] Can't add tabs after closing a tab
items.body:
OSX 10.13, Python 3.6.10, Bokeh 2.1.1
(using Bokeh server)

Clicking on the button in the MWE below adds new tabs to the layout, as expected. However, whenever I close one of the new tabs, the button no longer works (the callback function isn't called).

```python
from bokeh.io import curdoc
from bokeh.plotting import figure
from bokeh.models.widgets import Button
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, Tabs, Panel, Range1d
from numpy.random import default_rng
rng = default_rng()

doc = curdoc()

generator_btn = Button(height=40, width=150, label="Add a new tab!")
generator_pnl = Panel(title="Start Here!", child=generator_btn)
tabs = Tabs(tabs=[generator_pnl], height=800, width=800)

class NewTab:
    def __init__(self):
        self.tab_num = 0
    
    def __call__(self):
        print("Making a new tab!")
        self.tab_num += 1
        xd = rng.random(10)
        yd = rng.random(10)
        source = ColumnDataSource(data={'x': xd, 'y': yd})
        axr = Range1d(start=0, end=1)
        fig = figure(title="Test of ad hoc tabs", x_range=axr, y_range=axr, 
                     plot_height=800, plot_width=800)
        fig.diamond(x='x', y='y', source=source)
        panel = Panel(title="New Tab #{}".format(self.tab_num), child=fig, 
                      closable=True)
        tabs.tabs.append(panel)

generator_btn.on_click(NewTab())

doc.add_root(tabs)
```

items.title: [BUG] Unexpected behavior while svg export using level 'overlay'
items.body:
#### Software version info (bokeh, python)

Python: 3.6.10
Bokeh: 2.1.1

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
If a svg file is generated using bokeh there will be two files created. There was an issue for this alrady (talking about bokeh 2.1.1) : [#10273](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/10273)
This problem is connected to the one mentioned before, because if a figure has different layers, not all the data is stored in the same file. The example below uses two different `LabelSet`s, one with the `level='underlay'` and one with `level='overlay'`. After the export to svg the data of the second `LabelSet` is stored separately in a file with the same name as the first one with a suffix "_1" right before the file extension.
It was expected that both layers appear in the same svg export.

#### Minimal Example
This example generates two files named 'Labels.svg' and  'Labels_1.svg'. The second file contains the data of the variable 'labels_2'.
```
from bokeh.io import show, export_svgs
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, LabelSet
from bokeh.plotting import figure, output_notebook

output_notebook()

# the figure
p = figure(x_range=(0, 4), y_range=(0,3), plot_height=300, tools='' )

# some data
source = ColumnDataSource(dict(x=range(1,4), y_1=[1]*3, y_2=[2]*3, names=['a', 'b', 'c'], color_1=['green']*3, color_2=['red']*3))
# plot data as circle
p.circle(x='x', y='y_1', color='color_1', radius=0.3, alpha=0.3, source=source)
p.circle(x='x', y='y_2', color='color_2', radius=0.3, alpha=0.3, source=source)

# add arrow
labels_1 = LabelSet(x='x', y='y_1', text='names', level='underlay', text_align='center',
                  x_offset=0, y_offset=-8, source=source, render_mode='canvas')
labels_2 = LabelSet(x='x', y='y_2', text='names', level='overlay', text_align='center',
                  x_offset=0, y_offset=-8, source=source, render_mode='canvas')
p.add_layout(labels_1)
p.add_layout(labels_2)
show(p)

p.output_backend = "svg"
export_svgs(p, filename ='Labels.svg')
```

#### Screenshots
This is the html output in a jupyter notebook:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/89534218-e3ad5100-d7f4-11ea-9393-39c68f76616f.png)

This is a screenshot of 'Labels.svg':
![Labels](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/89536253-ea899300-d7f7-11ea-80da-5adf5521032a.png)
And this is a screenshot of 'Labels_1.svg':
![Labels_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/89536267-ed848380-d7f7-11ea-935a-4c2f210f7dbf.PNG)

items.title: [BUG] If axis label is added/removed, the layout is not changed right away
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0-26-g8888d176f

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
If you click on the button, the axis label should become visible right away. Instead, you need to pan the plot to make it appear.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.layouts import column
from bokeh.models import Button, CustomJS
from bokeh.plotting import figure, show

p = figure()
p.circle(0, 0)

b = Button()
b.js_on_click(CustomJS(args=dict(xaxis=p.xaxis[0]),
                       code="xaxis.axis_label = xaxis.axis_label == '' ? 'hello' : '';"))

show(column(p, b))
```

items.title: Autoload with widgets fails if earlier autoload does not specify widgets
items.body:
Some of the User's Guide examples with widgets do not render:

https://docs.bokeh.org/en/dev/docs/user_guide/layout.html#multiple-objects

Error is:

> Uncaught (in promise) Error: Model 'Select' does not exist. This could be due to a widget or a custom model not being registered before first usage.


By contrast, all the widgets on this page do render:

https://docs.bokeh.org/en/dev/docs/user_guide/interaction/widgets.html

Important observations:

* recently, bundle computation was made narrower: content that did not reference widgets no longer results in a widgets bundle being added to `js_urls`

* On the page that works, the first autoload script *does* have widgets. On the page that fails, the first autoload script does *not* have widgets.

My supposition is that the autoload script is broken, and will not load any additional bundles past whatever the first autoload script on a page requests. I further suppose this has in fact been broken for a long time, but was masked by the fact that until recently we unconditionally included all possible bundles in autoload, whether they were needed or not. 

A "quick fix" would be to return to the unconditional behavior, but hopefully we can find a real fix. 

cc @mattpap @philippjfr

items.title: Adding links to BEP 6 and BEP landing page to developer docs
items.body:
BEPs contain important information for (potential) contributors, especially [BEP 1](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki/BEP-1:-Issues-and-PRs-management) and (the recently updated) [BEP 6](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki/BEP-6:-Branching-and-Milestones). When reading through the developer docs for pr #10337, I noticed that only BEP 1 is linked in the Dev Guide.

 I'd suggest updating the [developer documentation landing page](https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/dev_guide.html) to include a link to the general [Wiki landing page on GitHub](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki) as well as a link to [BEP 6](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki/BEP-6:-Branching-and-Milestones) (in addition to the existing link to BEP 1).

 I'd be happy to open a pull request with those additions.

items.title: Change NumberArray to Float32Array?
items.body:
AFAICT WebGL does not support Float64 buffers. E.g. they are explicitly caught and excepted in three.js, trying to use them with ReGL generates bogus output (seems like the raw data is just being interpreted as Float32). And in Bokeh, the existing code definitely copies everything into `Float32Array` before  sending to buffers:
```
  74 :        this.vbo_s.set_data(0, new Float32Array(map(this.glyph.sradius, (s) => s*2)))
  172 :       this.vbo_x.set_data(0, new Float32Array(xx))
  173 :       this.vbo_y.set_data(0, new Float32Array(yy))
  176 :       this.vbo_a.set_data(0, new Float32Array(this.glyph._angle))
  181 :       this.vbo_s.set_data(0, new Float32Array(map(this.glyph.sradius, (s) => s*2)))
  183 :       this.vbo_s.set_data(0, new Float32Array(this.glyph._size))
```

Which I assume happens for a reason. All this copying seems pretty wasteful, but mostly has me wondering why we are using `Float64Array` as a default everywhere to begin with. It's been that way forever but I don't have any recollection of an actual discussion or decision. 

Would it make sense to change `NumberArray` to be `Float32Array` (and also to update a few explicit `Float64Array` instances left in the code base to be `NumberArray`)? It seems this would allow less copying in the webgl support eventually, but also reduce Bokeh's memory footprint in general. 

Alternatively, are there any *specific* situtations where 16 vs 7 sig digits is required? If so can we isolate those and change to `Float32Array` everywhere else?

Thoughts @philippjfr @mattpap @bokeh/dev ?

items.title: [FEATURE] cmap for VArea glyph
items.body:
**Idea**
I was looking for a function to draw a virtual area with a color map, like the one show in the figure below.
![goal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/88184257-c42dfa00-cc32-11ea-8d7a-1352c78c4bca.PNG)

This is the code how I created the figure.
```
import numpy as np
from bokeh.io import  show, output_notebook
from bokeh.plotting import figure
from bokeh.palettes import brewer

output_notebook()

N = 500
x = np.linspace(-2, 3, N)
y = np.linspace(0, 10, N)

y1 = np.zeros(N)
y2 = 10-x**2

d = np.zeros([N, N])
for j, _y in enumerate(y):
    for i, _x in enumerate(x):
        d[j][i] = _y if _y < 10 - _x**2 else -1
        
plot = figure(title=None,
              plot_width=300, 
              plot_height=300,
              min_border=0,
              toolbar_location=None
             )

palette = brewer["OrRd"][9]+('#ffffff',)

plot.image(image=[d], x=-2, y=0, dw=5, dh=10, palette=palette[::-1], level="image")
plot.line(x, y2)

show(plot)
```
**Wanted solution**
I was somehow hoping to get the same result while using the VArea glyph like the example in the example gallery, because my solution is ugly for a small number of ```N```. Furthermore it is not as smoth as the VArea if I zoom into the picture.
![latest](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/88185841-b4afb080-cc34-11ea-8ff9-c3e53542dd91.PNG)
```
import numpy as np

from bokeh.io import show
from bokeh.models import VArea, ColumnDataSource

N = 500
x = np.linspace(-2, 3, N)
y = np.linspace(0, 10, N)

y1 = np.zeros(N)
y2 = 10-x**2

source = ColumnDataSource(dict(x=x, y1=y1, y2=y2))

plot = figure(title=None,
              plot_width=300, 
              plot_height=300,
              min_border=0, 
              toolbar_location=None
             )

glyph = VArea(x="x", y1="y1", y2="y2", hatch_color="#f46d43", fill_alpha=0.2)
plot.add_glyph(source, glyph)
plot.line(x, y2)

show(plot)
```

**Additional comment**
This is not an urgent topic to me. I am just interested if this could be possible in the future and if someone else is interested in this functionality, too.

items.title: Plotting with transforms behavior change
items.body:
An application with a selected-point, constrained to move along a reference curve via interactive user control, is implemented using bokeh transforms. This works as expected in bokeh 2.0.2. In bokeh 2.1.0 (and 2.1.1), the web page excludes the associated plots, and errors are seen in the Javascript console of the client browser.

See bokeh discourse topic [Plotting changes between 2.0.2 and 2.1.x](https://discourse.bokeh.org/t/bokeh-plotting-changes-between-2-0-2-and-2-1-x/6004/3) for additional details.

A minimal reproducible example follows, which can highlight the problem with simple plot/glyph creation, excluding any interactive elements.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
"""
import numpy as np

from bokeh.plotting import figure, show
from bokeh.transform import transform

from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource
from bokeh.models import LinearInterpolator

# Referencce curve
x = np.linspace(0.0,1.0,1001)
y = np.tanh(np.pi*x)

Sref = ColumnDataSource(data=dict(x=x, y=y))

# Operating point constrained to reference curve
op = 301
Ssel = ColumnDataSource(data=dict(x=[x[op]], y=y[[op]]))

_li_x = LinearInterpolator(x='x', y='x', data=Sref, clip=False)
_js_x = transform('x', _li_x)
_li_y = LinearInterpolator(x='x', y='y', data=Sref, clip=False)
_js_y = transform('x', _li_y)


p = figure(width=400, height=300)
p.line(x='x', y='y', source=Sref)
p.inverted_triangle(x=_js_x, y=_js_y, source=Ssel, size=15, line_color='#000000', fill_color='#000000')

show(p)
```

items.title: [BUG] $name not being passed to hovertool for image plots

If you try to use $name in tooltips for image plots, then you just get the javascript error message:

An example would be taking your example at: https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide/tools.html#image-hover and adding ('name', '$name') to the TOOLTIP variable.

I believe this can be fixed changing this line of code:
https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/blob/5b1befb97ca2c4b3dc0f0d18690b8668d6481c96/bokehjs/src/lib/models/tools/inspectors/hover_tool.ts#L269

to include:
name: renderer_view.model.name

However I don't know enough about the internals of bokeh to know if this is correct - modifying identical looking code in bokeh.js did appear to fix it for me.

Thanks,
Sam

items.title: SVG backend doesn't respect NaN/non-finite values
items.body:
#### software version info (bokeh, python)
Python: 3.6.10
Bokeh: 2.1.1

#### Description of the observed behavior
The export_svg() function creates an image where some data is missing. If the figure is shown before and after the export function the changes become obvious.

#### Minimal example

[example_data.zip](https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/files/4924871/example_data.zip)

```
import pandas as pd

from bokeh.plotting import figure, show, output_notebook
from bokeh.palettes import d3
from bokeh.models import BoxAnnotation, Legend, HoverTool, LinearAxis, Range1d,  Circle
from bokeh.io import export_png, export_svgs

output_notebook()

data = pd.read_hdf('example_data.h5')

p = figure(title='missing values in svg export', 
           x_axis_label='Datetime', 
           y_axis_label='Data', 
           x_axis_type="datetime", 
           plot_width=1400, 
           plot_height=500,
           active_drag='box_zoom'
        )

colorset = list(d3['Category20'][20])

p.xaxis[0].formatter.days = '%d.%m.%Y'
p.xaxis.major_label_orientation = 3.14/3

index_min = data.index.min()
index_max = data.index.max()

_min = data.min().min()
_max = data.max().max()
_d = _max - _min if 0 < _max - _min else 1

p.y_range  = Range1d(_min-_d*0.05, _max+_d*0.05)

################# COLORED AREAS ################# 
boxes = []
my_renderers = []
# draw all sundays with a light gray shade into the figure
alldays = pd.date_range(start=index_min.date(), end=index_max.date())
saturdays = alldays[alldays.dayofweek == 6]
for date in saturdays:
    start = date+pd.DateOffset(minutes=15)
    end = date+pd.DateOffset(days=1)
    boxes.append(BoxAnnotation(left=start, right=end, fill_alpha=0.1, fill_color='grey'))
p.renderers.extend(boxes)

########## DATA HANDLING ################
names = data.columns
for i, name in enumerate(names):
    my_renderers.append(p.line(x=data.index.tz_localize(None), y=data[name], line_width=2, color=colorset[2*i], legend_label=name))
                
p.legend.visible = False
p.add_layout(Legend(items=p.legend[0].items, click_policy="hide", orientation='horizontal', spacing=20))
    
p.add_tools(HoverTool(tooltips="@y",renderers=my_renderers,mode='vline'))

print("Let's show the generated figure.")
show(p)

print("Export to png after this line.")
filepath = 'example_export'
export_png(p, filename = filepath + '.png')

print("Let's show the generated figure again.")
show(p)

print("Export to svg after this line.")
p.output_backend = "svg"
export_svgs(p, filename = filepath + '.svg')

print("Let's show the generated figure again after svg export.")
show(p)
print('This is unexpected.')
```

#### Screenshots
This is the output if the code runs in a jupyter notebook.

First the figure is shown right before any export.
![Step1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/87541043-e9ee5880-c6a0-11ea-9c29-7c12b9de1791.PNG)

Now the figure is exported to an image in png format. This works fine, nothing to complain about.
![Step2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/87541172-1f934180-c6a1-11ea-945c-9af9faab49d8.PNG)

Now the figure is exported to an image in svg format. The stored svg file contains the figure below.
![Step3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68053396/87541234-3a65b600-c6a1-11ea-90cd-73cb63f8a4f9.PNG)

#### Comment
I was trying to creat a simplier minimal example, but I was not successful.

I was able to reproduce this problem with different data sets, similar to the given one. As far as I know this problem only occurs with a datetime index.

items.title: [BUG] Slider values increment by 2x steps

The Slider values appear to increment by a factor of 2. I tested the rendering with Bokeh 2.1.1. on Chrome and Firefox.  Here's a sample:

```python
from bokeh.models import Slider
from bokeh import io
slider = Slider(start=0, end=9, value=0, step=1, title="foo")
```

items.title: [BUG]Path for Bokeh server application does not exist
items.body:
### FOLLOW THESE INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY

*ISSUES THAT DO NOT CONTAIN NECESSARY INFORMATION MAY BE CLOSED, IMMEDIATELY*

The issue tracker is NOT the place for general support. For questions and technical assistance, come join the [Bokeh  Project Discourse](https://discourse.bokeh.org).

For defects or deficiencies, please provide *ALL OF THE FOLLOWING*:

#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior

```
)
```

items.title: Housekeeping: Update python idioms
items.body:
I had a look through some of the source code and noticed (perfectly working) code that is using a bit out of date coding styles that are likely remnants from Python 2.6 and 2.7.

For example things like
* `IOError`/`EnvironmentError` (has been merged into `OSError` in Python 3.3+)
* `class ClassName(object):` style declarations (`object` is redundant since Python 3)
* `io.open` (once used for 2.7/3+ cross-compatibility, now redundant)
* `x = set([... for ... in ...])` which can be shortened to a set comprehension `{... for ... in ...}` (supported since Python 2.7)
* some places that are particularly amenable to f-strings (Python 3.6+)
* `super(ClassName, self).(...)` can be shortened to `super().(...)` with Python 3+

Happy to prepare a PR for this, but would like to check first if there is any interest in doing this.

items.title: [BUG] compiler.json is half of the shipped release artifact's weight
items.body:
We realized ~half of the bokeh conda distro (50MB) is a seemingly unnecessary  file `compiler.json`: https://discourse.bokeh.org/t/the-purpose-of-compiler-json/4721 . Additional files may also be unnecessary according to https://jcristharif.com/conda-docker-tips.html , but afaict, compiler.json is a lot of bang for very little buck. This is becoming a performance tax on the pydata ecosystem, such as install speed, docker builds, CI, etc.

Thread: https://twitter.com/xhochy/status/1280488453780770816

Real-world docker repro: 

* before: https://hub.docker.com/layers/graphistry/graphistry-forge-base/v2.30.22/images/sha256-d7cb047757e6c4cc38687a2263adbe49b49a502a13347d1f249ad96afdcde729?context=repo

* after: https://hub.docker.com/layers/graphistry/graphistry-forge-base/v2.30.23/images/sha256-a03c4ab2836a9da1629bbcb9571166566ae9c4015d24f1a7419c0658febcf308?context=repo

* note this line for current work around in `after` in the big layer: 
``` 
find /conda -follow -type f -name '*.js.map' -delete   \
  && ( find /conda/envs/rapids/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bokeh -follow -type f -name '*.js' ! -name '*.min.js' -delete || echo "rm bokeh fail 1" )    \
 && ( find /conda/envs/rapids/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bokeh -follow -type f -name 'compiler.json' ! -name '*.min.js' -delete || echo "rm bokeh fail 2" )

```

I'm not familiar enough with the project nor compiler.json on the appropriate fix, but thought the heads up would help.

items.title: [FEATURE] Add a DocumentReady event
items.body:
In many cases you want your application to display something as quickly as possible. In the current design of bokeh server everything has to be initialized in the initial request. One solution to alleviate this issue would be to defer any expensive computation on initialization until after we have actually rendered something to screen. However currently there is no way to tell when the frontend is done initializing the rendered Document. 

Therefore I propose adding a BokehEvent which signals when the Document is ready (or in BokehJS terminology, when it is idle).

items.title: Passing DataFrame.to_dict() type to ColumnSourceData.stream Doesn't Cause Graph to Refresh
items.body:
I have a pandas.DataFrame that I converted to a dictionary using pandas.DataFrame.to_dict(). The resultant dictionary is something that while Bokeh's ColumnSourceData.stream() will accept, it does not cause the graph to dynamically refresh as stream() is called.

I had to break out the data in the DataFrame into a list, transpose it, then use a for...loop to generate a new dictionary with variable-based key names in order get it to work with the stream() function. The reason is to_dict() creates a dictionary like so:

myDict = { 'x': 1}

But Bokeh's stream function expects the format of the dictionary to be the following:

myDict = {'x': [1]}   #Note that "figures one" is enclosed in square brackets.

I don't know if this is a Bokeh limitation or a limitation of pandas. Needless to say, this took me over 48 hours to figure out.

Thanks.

items.title: Deprecate Oval?
items.body:
We currently have both `Oval` and `Ellipse`, which are nearly identical. There have been approximately ~zero support questions or issues about either of these (that I have observed) in the last 8 years, so my opinion is that there is little reason to maintain both. 

I would propose to deprecate `Oval` (which has the more complicated implementation) now, and remove it in Bokeh 3.0. 

Thoughts @bokeh/dev?

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior

When I use SaveTool to save the image, the generated file is not from the full plot but only from a small area of it. Even if I change the size of the plot_width and plot_height, I can't download the full image.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue

Plot file:
```
from bokeh.layouts import row
from bokeh.palettes import Set1_6
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource
from bokeh.models.widgets import Panel
from bokeh.models.widgets import Tabs
from bokeh.plotting import figure
from bokeh.transform import factor_cmap

import pandas as pd


def researches():
    
    data = {
        'x_axis': ['SEMINARIO', 'CONFERENCIA', 'CONGRESSO', 'OUTRA', 'COMUNICACAO', 'SIMPOSIO'],
        'values': ['7', '19', '11', '24', '32', '5']

    # Getting Courses and Degrees
    types = list(df_plot['x_axis'])
    amount = df_plot.columns.tolist()
    amount = amount[1:]

    # Getting data source
    source = ColumnDataSource(data=df_plot)

    plot = figure(x_range=types, plot_height=400, plot_width=600, title='Curso de curta duração',
                  toolbar_location='right',

    plot.vbar(x='x_axis', top=amount[0], source=source, width=.2, legend_field='x_axis',

    layout_graph = row(plot)

    # Creating Tabs

    tabs = Tabs(tabs=[bar_panel])

    return tabs

```

items.title: Improve responsiveness when hovering over many points

#### My Pain

I would like to use Bokeh plots in my applications but sometimes they feel slow and sluggish.

An example of this is plots with many points. The many points by them selves is not the main problem. The main problem is hovering.

If the users hovers over the Bokeh plot it becomes unresponsive and my fan turns on. 

I suspect its due to collecting and showing tool tips for many points

My fear is that my users turn away from my apps because they appear slow or dead.

#### Example

https://ferret.pmel.noaa.gov/osmc/dashboard

items.title: [BUG] bokeh js v2.x legacy libraries
items.body:
Hello,

I posted a [more detailed version of this question](https://discourse.bokeh.org/t/bokeh-2-x-legacy-js/5862) on the Bokeh Discourse and it was suggested that I open an issue here.

*Main Issue*
Using Bokeh version 2.02 or version 2.1.1 I am unable to load the Bokeh legacy libraries. I tried
`>bokeh.resources.Resources(mode="cdn",legacy=True).render()`
which gives a list of libraries including links of the form
https://cdn.bokeh.org/bokeh/release/bokeh-2.1.1.legacy.min.js
These links do not appear to be valid (getting 403 error on access) for these two versions but they are accessible for v2.0.0.

*Additional Question*
I also asked an additional question about where to find documentation on the differences between the main versions of a Bokeh JS library and its corresponding legacy version (e.g. between `bokeh-2.1.1.legacy.min.js` and `bokeh-2.1.1.min.js`). How can one determine what functionality is lost using the legacy versions? Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks very much: I really appreciate the continued support for the legacy versions - we have an audience that is restricted to IE11 and it's great to still have an option.

Andrew

Bokeh 2.1.0

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
If you plot rects and provide factor ranges to the figure that don't include some of the data points, the rects will be misplaced.
In the example below, notice how the circles are positioned properly.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.io import show
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource
from bokeh.plotting import figure

ds = ColumnDataSource(dict(x=list('AAABBBCCC'), y=list('ABCABCABC')))

p = figure(x_range=list('BC'), y_range=list('CB'))
p.rect(x='x', y='y', width=0.9, height=0.9, source=ds)
p.circle(x='x', y='y', radius=0.2, color='red', source=ds)

show(p)
```

#### Screenshots or screencasts of the bug in action
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4410314/85312454-85841300-b4bf-11ea-8c25-2568fad9d61a.png)

items.title: [BUG] Band is not updated when the model is changed
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.io import curdoc
from bokeh.layouts import column
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, Button, Band
from bokeh.plotting import figure

ds = ColumnDataSource(dict(x=[0, 1], y=[0, 1]))

p = figure(x_range=(-1, 2), y_range=(-1, 10))
bn = Band(lower=0, upper=1, base='x', source=ds)
p.add_layout(bn)

b = Button()


def update():
    bn.upper = bn.upper + 1


b.on_click(update)

curdoc().add_root(column(p, b))
```

items.title: BEP 7: Decision making
items.body:
ref: https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki/BEP-7:-Decision-Making

In order to apply for organizational GH sponsor status, I had to provide a model for group decision making. I would like to codify that model that I sent them (modulo refinements resulting from this discussion) publicly in BEP 7.

#### Rationale

This proposal aims to make the high level decision making of the Bokeh core team and NumFOCUS committee more transparent and accountable.

#### What is the process

The model I described was more or less this:

> Official decision making follows a model of unanimous consent. Technical or financial proposals are put before the relevant team. Proposals may be put forth as Issues, PRs, topics on the Project Discourse, or as an email to all team members, as appropriate.  If there is no comment or objection within first timebox, then the proposal is deemed to pass. If there is comment or objection, then discussion may proceed for the duration of a second timebox. If any objections are resolved n that time, the proposal is deemed to pass. Otherwise, I vote will be taken among all the team members.
>
> The timebox durations may be stipulated by the proposer, however may not be shorter than three days. 

#### When will this process apply

* any expenditure of funds always be a recorded decision
* "big" technical proposals  (specifically: if any team member asks for a recorded decision)

This process is not meant to impede day-to-day development. Standard work for bugfixes and small features will not normally come under this process, and only require an approval before merge. It is expected most recorded decisions will be financial matters. 


#### Where are decisions recorded

I propose that a read-only public Google sheet be created to record official decisions. The sheet should have a row for each proposal gives:

* date
* brief proposal desription
* any relevant links or references
* resolution (agreed by consent, agreed by vote, denied by vote)

The spreadsheet should be linked in the BEP document. 

cc @bokeh/core

items.title: Issues / Changelog script will need update
items.body:
cc @lexicalunit 

In light of the process changes that will come out of #10177, the `scripts/issues.py` tool will need updates. 

also ref: https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/wiki/BEP-1:-Issues-and-PRs-management

There are three modes that this script will be used:

#### Release Validation Mode

Would like to be able to run the script in automation to ensure that all the relevant issues are labeled appropriately, etc. Some criteria:

* Relevant issues/PRs are those for the current specified milestone
* All issues in the milestone should be closed, with a `reso:completed`
* All PRs in the milestone should be closed/merged with `status:accepted`
* Any PR with a `type` label (an "issue PR") also needs `reso:completed`
* There should only ever be one `reso` or `status` label applied.
* All issues sholud have a `type`
* Allowed types: bug, feature, task
* Nothing should have TRIAGE label
* All issues/PRs should be closed 

nice to have: verify that any plain PRs in the milestone link to an issue that is in the milestone, verify that for issues "closed by" a PR that that PR is in the milestone

```shell
python milestone.py 2.1.1  --check-only
```

#### Release Update Mode

Would like to be able to run the script in automation to update the CHANGELOG with lists of issues (or "issue PRs") from the current milestone. 

* Group by bugfix, feature, task
* Include component label, if present

```shell
python milestone.py 2.1.1  # Implies a check
```

items.title: [BUG] `GeoJSONDataSource` incorrectly processes `MultiPolygon` geometry type
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.io import show
from bokeh.models import GeoJSONDataSource, GMapOptions
from bokeh.plotting import gmap

data = """{
  "type": "FeatureCollection",
  "features": [
    {
      "id": "0",
      "type": "Feature",
      "properties": {"plotted_data": 98.7805281},
      "geometry": {
        "type": "MultiPolygon",
        "coordinates": [
          [
            [
              [-98.11372330298127, 30.48557591185999],
              [-98.11336081363682, 30.48592948588511],
              [-98.11319281272974, 30.486219485691766]
            ]
          ],
          [
            [
              [-98.10916428343725, 30.492520477204575],
              [-98.10904979183817, 30.49274448101661],
              [-98.10904600029392, 30.492747999424935]
            ]
          ]
        ]
      }
    }
  ]
}
"""
data_source = GeoJSONDataSource(geojson=data)

map_options = GMapOptions(lat=30.2861, lng=-97.7394, map_type="roadmap", zoom=11)

plot = gmap(%YOUR_API_KEY%, map_options)

plot.patches('xs', 'ys', source=data_source,
             line_color='black', line_width=0.25, fill_alpha=1)

show(plot)
```

`GeoJSONDataSource._add_geometry` has this function:
```typescript
    function flatten(acc: Position[], item: Position[]) {
      return acc.concat([[NaN, NaN, NaN]]).concat(item)
    }
```
And it's incompatible with this code in `proj4/lib/checkSanity.js`:
```javascript
        if (typeof Number.isFinite === 'function') {
            if (Number.isFinite(num)) {
                return;
            }
            throw new TypeError('coordinates must be finite numbers');
        }
```

Given that the same `flatten` function is used for the `MultiLineString` geometry type, it might also be broken.

#### Stack traceback and/or browser JavaScript console output
```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: coordinates must be finite numbers
    at checkCoord (checkSanity.js:13)
    at Object.default_1 [as default] (checkSanity.js:4)
    at Object.transform [as default] (transform.js:18)
    at transformer (core.js:10)
    at Object.forward (core.js:81)
    at project_xy (projections.js:32)
    at Object.project_xsys (projections.js:44)
    at PatchesView.set_data (glyph.js:187)
    at GlyphRendererView.set_data (glyph_renderer.js:123)
    at GlyphRendererView.lazy_initialize (glyph_renderer.js:68)
```

items.title: [BUG] Tools in toolbar flickering and occasionally ignores clicks when HoverTool and hover glyph used
items.body:
## Software info
OS: Windows 10
Browser: Chrome 83.0.4103.97
Python: 3.8.3
Bokeh: 2.1.0 - also tested on 2.0.2

Initially reported at https://discourse.bokeh.org/t/toolbar-tools-difficult-to-toggle-when-hovertool-is-active/5790

## Issue
When plotting a circle while also supplying the renderer with a hover glyph, the HoverTool causes tools on the toolbar to flicker when hovering over them. This also occasionally results in my clicks not registering when clicking on a tool to toggle its state, which is the main burden.

A few things to note:
- This only happens if the HoverTool's renderers contains at least one GlyphRenderer with a hover glyph.
- I have also tested this with the Square and Line glyphs, and the issue is also present with those.
- I originally noticed this issue while working in a Django environment, but the issue also happens in standalone mode.

## Screen recording
In the screen recording below you can see the flickering, which stops as soon as I disable the HoverTool. The gif has a pretty low framerate, but on my screen it's much worse obviously.

![0Tg4Et8GNm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39745476/84941335-85f86480-b0e1-11ea-86aa-b985273fed67.gif)

## Code to reproduce the issue
```python
import numpy as np

from bokeh.plotting import figure, show
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, HoverTool

x = np.random.randn(100)
y = np.random.randn(100)

data = dict(x=x, y=y)
source = ColumnDataSource(data=data)

p = figure(width=300, height=300)

r = p.circle(x='x', y='y', size=10, source=source, hover_fill_color='red')

h = HoverTool(renderers=[r])
p.add_tools(h)

show(p)
```

items.title: [FEATURE] Allow any number in spinner using step=None
items.body:
In input type number specification an `any` step can be set allowing any number 

> A string value of any means that no stepping is implied, and any value is allowed (barring other constraints, such as min and max).

The actual behavior of Bokeh `Spinner`, throw a javascript error if `step` is set to `None`
Moreover the smallest `step` allowed is 1e-16 so a value of 1.532512855486e-16 will be rounded to 2e-16 at best

It could be intersting if the `step` is set to `None`, to allow the user to enter any number with any precision

items.title: [BUG] Incorrect type of `Select.options`
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
`Select.options` says that it accepts 
```python
Either(List(Either(String, Tuple(Either(Int, String), String))),
       Dict(String, List(Either(String, Tuple(Either(Int, String), String))))
```

In reality, it doesn't accept `Int`s there as
1. `Select.value` can only be a string
2. `Select` in BokehJS doesn't use integers at all

An easy solution is to just drop `Int` from that field descriptor.
A (maybe) better solution is to allow integers in `Select.value` and `Select` in BokehJS. But it would require remembering the right type and converting the currently selected value in HTML to it so the correct type is stored in the model and used in every callback.

items.title: [BUG] Using CDS field as color for nonselection_fill_color gets the wrong colors when using a view
items.body:
Python 3.6.0, Bokeh 2.0.2, Pandas 0.25.3

#### Issue:
when setting the nonselection_fill_color of a bokeh glyph to be the name of a field in a CDS, the color is improperly represented if the glyph is given a CDSview

#### Example:
```
from bokeh.plotting import figure, show, output_file
from bokeh.sampledata.iris import flowers
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, CDSView, IndexFilter
from bokeh.palettes import OrRd9
import pandas as pd

COLORS = OrRd9[::-1]
N_COLORS = len(COLORS)
def get_colors(var):
        c_data = data.data[var]
        if len(c_data) > N_COLORS:
            groups = pd.qcut(c_data, N_COLORS)
        else:
            groups = pd.Categorical(c_data)
        data.data['color'] = [COLORS[xx] for xx in list(groups.codes)]

data = ColumnDataSource(data=flowers)
view = CDSView(source=data, filters=[IndexFilter(list(range(50,100)))])
get_colors('petal_length')

p = figure(title = "Iris Morphology", tools=["tap", "save"])
p.xaxis.axis_label = 'Petal Length'
p.yaxis.axis_label = 'Petal Width'

p1 = p.circle(x="petal_length", y="petal_width",
         color="color", size=10,
         nonselection_alpha=1, nonselection_fill_color="color",
         selection_fill_color='blue',
         source=data, view=view)

output_file("iris.html", title="iris.py example")
show(p)
```

#### Screenshots or screencasts of the bug in action

colors showing up in order (low to high from left to right) as expected:
![bokeh_plot (4)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49727347/84436430-6ce34580-ac01-11ea-9c39-290c167cabb8.png)


color order changes when selected (the issue):
![bokeh_plot (3)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49727347/84436424-69e85500-ac01-11ea-9539-e656db5c0d59.png)


If we turn off the view, the order is preserved:
![bokeh_plot (2)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49727347/84436391-5e952980-ac01-11ea-8443-11eb9cfb9653.png)

```
    "y":{"0":79.95,"1":78.6,"2":78.02,"3":76.68,"4":75.14,"5":74.17,"6":70.51,"7":69.16,"8":67.24,"9":66.47,"10":65.89,"11":65.5,"12":65.5}
}, final=false)
```

Have seen Typed Arrays get represented in this format it other contexts. I would not be surprised to learn that this is a general issue in other places as well. It would be nice to return as "ndarray" types but would also settle for plain lists. 

cc @mattpap

items.title: [BUG] `TileRenderer` ignores the `visible` property
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0rc1

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
`TileRenderer` should take into account the `visible` property. Both if passed to its constructor and if changed in runtime if using Bokeh server.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.io import show
from bokeh.plotting import figure
from bokeh.tile_providers import CARTODBPOSITRON, get_provider

p = figure(x_range=(-2000000, 6000000), y_range=(-1000000, 7000000),
           x_axis_type="mercator", y_axis_type="mercator")

p.add_tile(get_provider(CARTODBPOSITRON), visible=False)

show(p)
```
The root cause is that `TileRenderer` just doesn't check `visible` at all. It seems like every renderer checks this property. Maybe it should be checked at a higher level?

items.title: [BUG] `js_on_event` doesn't work when used in a callback
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.1.0rc1

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
Any call to `js_on_event` when using `bokeh serve` should add the corresponding callback.
But since it modifies the `js_event_callbacks` property in-place, the frontend is never notified about the change.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
```python
from bokeh.io import curdoc
from bokeh.layouts import column
from bokeh.models import CustomJS, Button

b1 = Button(label="console.log")


def set_js_on_click():
    b1.js_on_click(CustomJS(code="console.log('hello');"))


b2 = Button(label='Set callback')
b2.on_click(set_js_on_click)

curdoc().add_root(column(b2, b1))
```

items.title: 2020 Season of Docs Proposal
items.body:
Technical writing experience
============================

Transformative technology for parents
-------------------------------------

Blog post detailing the technologies used to power Winnie.

https://winnie.com/blog/transformative-technology-for-parents

Plugging in to the Mattermost CLI
---------------------------------

Blog post on my open source contribution to the Mattermost command line interface (CLI).

https://medium.com/@santosjs/plugging-in-to-the-mattermost-cli-8cdcef2bd1f6

Intuit gets Groovy
------------------

Blog post on the QuickBooks Engineering Blog summarizing my experience with the Groovy programming language.

https://quickbooks-engineering.intuit.com/intuit-gets-groovy-4c1f85f9ab4a

Project proposal
================

**Open source organization name:** Bokeh

**Open source project name:** Bokeh

**The name of your proposed technical writing project:** Improving the Documentation Experience for Bokeh Developers

Current documentation state
---------------------------

Bokeh has done a tremendous job in documenting visualization use cases in the User Guide [1]. In the Reference [2] you can find all the API methods afforded by their models. The documentation has grown large and there is no easy way to find misspellings, repetition errors, or formatting issues in the text [3]. 

You can find dozens of code examples on how you might use Bokeh with your own data on GitHub. You can find some examples inline in the documentation but a lot of examples are missing [4]. Users may spend a considerable amount of time trying to figure out how a tool works without realizing there exists code they can reference. For example, you can use Themes to style a plot on Bokeh but these examples exist in the Reference when one would expect to find them in the User Guide [5][6]. 

Lastly, there is a section in the User Guide that thoroughly covers adding new capabilities to Bokeh with inline extensions. This is not the case for pre-built extensions. A small section detailing pre-built extensions and some commands exists but there is no guidance on how to build and manage them [7].

Proposed documentation state
----------------------------

**Automated spell checking**

Vale Linter [8] is available as a GitHub Action [9]. It checks for spelling, repetition, and styling issues on every pull request. Automated checks would find existing errors in the documentation to fix. This technology would prevent future errors from creeping into the documentation. Vale Linter can also enforce a consistent style across all documentation. For example, suggesting the term "JavaScript" over "Javascript," preferring active voice over passive voice, etc.

**Additional cross-referencing across docs**

Different parts of the documentation should link back and forth for a more complete discussion. Users interested in learning more about a topic should be able to navigate to the Reference from the User Guide. Users interested in seeing an example of an API method should also be able navigate to the User Guide from the Reference. All examples found in the GitHub respository should exist inline in the documentation.

**A complete tutorial on pre-built Bokeh extensions**

Bokeh is the standard when it comes to simple use cases for visualization. At the same time, advanced users with specific cases can add new capabilities with extensions. Bokeh provides the scaffolding for users to get started with pre-built extensions but the documentation for this scaffolding is lacking. A  complete tutorial on setting up and creating pre-built extensions would make up for this. This tutorial would cover initializing and building extensions. It would also cover deploying and distributing them on npm, PiPy, and Anaconda.

Timeline
--------

**Pre-community bonding (present -  08/16)**

* Stay active as a contributor by tackling documentation issues
* Start a friction log to keep track of areas of documentation needing improvements

**Community bonding (08/17 - 09/13)**

* Establish project requirements
* Schedule a time to meet with mentors
* Agree on method of providing progress and updates

**Week 1 (09/14 - 9/20)**

* Set up and test Vale to check for existing spelling and repetition errors
* Identify terms to ignore that cause spelling errors like http, Bokeh, JupyterLab, etc.
* Add a new text file with list of terms to ignore when checking for spelling errors

**Week 2 (09/21 - 09/27)**
**Week 3 (09/28 - 10/04)**

* Identify suggested terms to use throughout documentation for consistency
* Add a new style guide for suggested terms
* Configure Vale to run on every pull request submitted to Bokeh

**Week 4 (10/05 - 10/11)**
**Week 5 (10/12 - 10/18)**

* Start working on improving cross-referencing across Bokeh documentation
* Identify existing Bokeh examples not shown in-line in documentation
* Link examples in the documentation to the source code location on GitHub

**Week 6 (10/19 - 10/25)**
**Week 7 (10/26 - 11/01)**
* Review topics covered in the User Guide
* Identify topics to link to sections in the Reference Guide

**Week 8 (11/02 - 11/08)**

* Create and customize a pre-built extension using the commands Bokeh provides
* Write down steps taken, errors encountered, etc. and come up with a template for the tutorial

**Week 9 (11/09 - 11/15)**

* Start on tutorial for pre-built extensions
* Study existing extensions and how they’re deployed

**Week 10 (11/16 - 11/22)**

* Deploy pre-built extensions
* Add deployment instructions to tutorial
* Wrap up tutorial

**Week 11 (11/23 - 11/29)**

* Finish remaining tasks
* Start working on Season of Docs project report

**Week 12 (11/30 - 12/05)**

* Finish project report
* Submit project report to Google

Commitments
-----------

I live in the Pacific Daylight Time (PDT) timezone. I have a full-time job so most of my commitments to Season of Docs will be throughout the week in the mornings/evenings and on weekends. If this schedule does not work with Bokeh or any of the mentors, I am open to finding suitable times to collaborate and connect.

References
----------
1. User Guide - https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/user_guide.html
2. Reference - https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/reference.html
3. Documentation spelling and formatting - https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/8448
4. Include example code of PolyEditTool and PolyDrawTool Docs - https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/9962
5. Add mention of Themes to "Styling Visual Attributes" docs page - https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/9007
6. Reference Guide should link to Users Guide where appropriate. - https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/9363
7. Documentation for Prebuilt Extensions - https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/issues/9523
8. Vale - https://errata.ai/vale/
9. Vale Linter - https://github.com/marketplace/actions/vale-linter

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
Background:
I have a holoviews plot with datashader that I serve with bokeh. I want this plot to be displayed in a react app with react widgets. To make this work I pull the server session and manipulate the widgets with flask and provide the resulting script tag via an API for the react application.

To manipulate the widgets I pull the session from my bokeh server and modify the server document. I expect the resulting script tag to contain the new modified session.

But instead, the resulting script does not generate anything from the session. Right after I reload the flask app (flask is in auto reload mode) the session gets loaded.

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue
This version only works if I reload the flask server and only adapts for one change in the session.
```
@app.route("/plot")
def plot_page():

    with pull_session(url=app_url) as session:

        session.document.roots[0].children[5].children[0].children[0].children[0].value = "Magma"
        script = server_session(None,session_id=session.id, url=app_url)
        print("Script tag generated")
    
        return render_template("embed.html", script=script, template="Flask")
```
The other version of the code displays the widgets with the correct modification, but the plot does not adapt to these settings and the interactivity which the datashader provides gets lost.
```
@app.route("/plot")
def plot_page():

    with pull_session(url=app_url) as session:

        session.document.roots[0].children[5].children[0].children[0].children[0].value = "Magma"
        session.push()
        script = server_session(None,session_id=session.id, url=app_url)
        print("Script tag generated")
    
        return render_template("embed.html", script=script, template="Flask")
```

items.title: [BUG] Button labels do not update after invoking callbacks with bokeh >= 2.*.*
items.body:
OS and Software RHEL, python 3.6, firefox 77.0.1, Chrome 83.0.4103.97, IE 11, bokeh server

Callback events do not update button labels with bokeh >= 2.*.*
Code runs perfectly with bokeh 1.4.0

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue

```
from bokeh.io import curdoc
from bokeh.io import curdoc, show
from bokeh.layouts import row, widgetbox, gridplot
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource, DataTable
from bokeh.models.widgets import Slider, TextInput, Div, Button, Slider
from bokeh.models.widgets import CheckboxButtonGroup, DatePicker, RadioButtonGroup
from bokeh.models.widgets import CheckboxGroup, RadioGroup
from bokeh.models.widgets import TableColumn, Select, Dropdown
from bokeh.layouts import gridplot, grid, widgetbox, column
from bokeh.events import ButtonClick
import time

def predict(event):
    i=0
    for i in range(10):
        print("Clicked Predict Button")
        button_predict.button_type = "warning"
        button_predict.label = "Computing started for loop {}".format(i)
        time.sleep(10)

div_text_intro = Div(text= """Reproduce Bug with non-updatable Button labels""")

# Predict Button
button_predict = Button(label="Predict", button_type="success")
# Register callback
button_predict.on_event(ButtonClick, predict)

curdoc().add_root(div_text_intro)
curdoc().add_root(button_predict)

```

#### Stack traceback and/or browser JavaScript console output
unfortunately there are no errors in python or browser dev consoles (css, js)

items.title: [FEATURE] EditTool.empty_value should support
items.body: It is frequently useful to add a string column to a glyph that is being edited using a `EditTool` but for some reason I did not allow string types in my initial implementation. I suggest simply adding String to the empty_value definition.

items.title: [BUG] Either property seemingly ignoring String property in certain cases
items.body:
The EditTool defines a `empty_value` property as follows:

```python
    empty_value = Either(Bool, Int, Float, Date, Datetime, Color, String, help="""
    Defines the value to insert on non-coordinate columns when a new
    glyph is inserted into the ``ColumnDataSource`` columns, e.g. when a
    circle glyph defines 'x', 'y' and 'color' columns, adding a new
    point will add the x and y-coordinates to 'x' and 'y' columns and
    the color column will be filled with the defined empty value.
    """)
```

However if you try to give it a string it errors:

```python
BoxEditTool(empty_value='blah')
```

```
ValueError: expected an element of either Bool, Int, Float, Date, Datetime or Color, got 'blah'
```

This is seemingly bcause the `String` property is dropped, which becomes apparent when looking at the `Either` property:

```python
from bokeh.models import EditTool
EditTool.empty_value.property._type_params
```

```
[<bokeh.core.property.primitive.Bool at 0x11b1715d0>,
 <bokeh.core.property.primitive.Int at 0x11b171610>,
 <bokeh.core.property.primitive.Float at 0x11b171650>,
 <bokeh.core.property.datetime.Date at 0x11b171690>,
 <bokeh.core.property.datetime.Datetime at 0x11b1716d0>,
 <bokeh.core.property.color.Color at 0x11b171710>]
```

bokeh==2.0.2, 
Windows 10 Home Version10.0.18363 Build 18363

Non-Bundled Plugins: org.exbin.deltahex.intellij, ru.meanmail.plugin.requirements

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
Expected html plot but addition got warning:
\venv\lib\site-packages\bokeh\resources.py:107: ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.TextIOWrapper name=‘C:\…\venv\lib\site-packages\bokeh\_sri.json’ mode=‘r’ encoding=‘cp1252’> _SRI_HASHES = json.load(open(join(ROOT_DIR, “_sri.json”)))

#### Complete, minimal, self-contained example code that reproduces the issue

```
df is a pandas dataframe 40,000 rows and 7 columns, float

    output_file(f'{data_path()}{plot_title}.html')
    if df.shape[1] > 2:
        colors = Category20[df.shape[1]]  # limited to 20 colors
    else:
        colors = ['#1f77b4', '#aec7e8']  # why do palettes have a min of 3?
    p = figure(title=plot_title, x_axis_label='Time(s)', y_axis_label=left_axis_label,
               x_range=(df.Time[0], df.Time.iloc[-1] * 1.3))
    for i, col in enumerate(df.columns):
        if col != 'Time': 
            p.line(x='Time', y=col, source=df, legend_label=col, color=colors[i])
    p.legend.click_policy = "hide"
    show(p)

```

#### Stack traceback and/or browser JavaScript console output

C:\Users\.....\GitHub\MultimodeEPGTest\venv\lib\site-packages\bokeh\resources.py:107:

items.title: [BUG] Model.serializable_attributes method removed in Bokeh master
items.body:
In bokeh master and therefore the coming release the `Model.serializable_attributes` method has been removed without warning as far as I can tell. We use this method in Panel in crucial codepaths and this currently breaks Panel entirely. I'd be happy to migrate to a different codepath, however I would prefer if there was at least a deprecation cycle here.

Cc: @mattpap @bryevdv

items.title: BokehDeprecationWarnings with Bokeh v 2.02
items.body:
Hi 
I am using nanoQC ( https://github.com/wdecoster/nanoQC) which uses Bokeh to plot the analysis of long read reads but while using I am getting errors **"BokehDeprecationWarning: 'legend' keyword is deprecated, use explicit 'legend_label', 'legend_field', or 'legend_group' keywords instead".** 
Any possible solution or update on it?
Someone from the previous version has reported  (https://github.com/PatrikHlobil/Pandas-Bokeh/issues/51) and it seems you have fixed it but this is actually not the case of latest release.

Please have a look.
Thanks

items.title: Error when plot is redrawn
items.body:
I am using the below script in python 3.7 and bokeh 2.02 on jupyter notebook . When I initiate the code for the first time the graph is created but once cancelled and the code is run again,  "Models must be owned by only a single document, YearsTicker(id='1166', ...) is already in a doc" error message shows up. 



`from bokeh.io import output_file,show,curdoc,output_notebook
from bokeh.models import ColumnDataSource,DatetimeTickFormatter,HoverTool,SingleIntervalTicker,Slider
from bokeh.plotting import figure
from bokeh.layouts import row,column
import pandas as pd

CONF_URL = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/master/csse_covid_19_data/csse_covid_19_time_series/time_series_covid19_confirmed_global.csv'
DEAD_URL = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/master/csse_covid_19_data/csse_covid_19_time_series/time_series_covid19_deaths_global.csv'
RECV_URL = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19/master/csse_covid_19_data/csse_covid_19_time_series/time_series_covid19_recovered_global.csv'

covid_conf_ts = pd.read_csv(CONF_URL)
covid_dead_ts = pd.read_csv(DEAD_URL)
covid_recv_ts = pd.read_csv(RECV_URL)

def process_data(data,cntry,window):
    conf_ts = data
    conf_ts_cntry = conf_ts[conf_ts['Country/Region']==cntry]    
    final_dataset = conf_ts_cntry.T[4:].sum(axis='columns').diff().rolling(window=window).mean()[40:]
    df = pd.DataFrame(final_dataset,columns=['Total'])
    df.reset_index(level=0, inplace=True)   
    df = pd.DataFrame(df)
    return df

def plot1(df,cntry,window):
    df = process_data(df,cntry,window)
    df['index']=pd.to_datetime(df['index'])
    df=ColumnDataSource(df)
    plot=figure(title='US',x_axis_label='date',plot_width=450,x_axis_type="datetime")
    plot.line(x='index',y='Total',line_width=3,source=df)
    #plot.xaxis.formatter = DatetimeTickFormatter(days = ['%m/%d', '%a%d'])
    #plot.xaxis.ticker = SingleIntervalTicker(interval=15)
    plot.add_tools(HoverTool(
    tooltips=[
        ( "Date",   "@index{%F}"),
        ( 'y',  '@{Total}{f}' ), # use @{ } for field names with spaces
            ],
        formatters={
        '@index' : 'datetime', # use 'datetime' formatter for 'date' field
        '@Total' : 'printf',   # use 'printf' formatter for 'adj close' field
                                  # use default 'numeral' formatter for other fields
    },

    # display a tooltip whenever the cursor is vertically in line with a glyph
    mode='vline'
    ))

    return plot

p1=plot1(covid_conf_ts,'US',3)
p2=plot1(covid_dead_ts,'US',3)
p3=plot1(covid_recv_ts,'US',3)


output_file('try.html')
layout=row(p1,p2,p3)
show(layout)


`

[BUG] `cd sphinx; make serve` doesn't work
items.body:
#### ALL software version info (bokeh, python, notebook, OS, browser, any other relevant packages)
Bokeh 2.0.2-76-ga417746c9

#### Description of expected behavior and the observed behavior
The page at https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/dev_guide/documentation.html mentions that it's possible to run `make serve` to serve the documentation locally. But running it results in:
```
Exception in thread Thread-2:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/p-himik/soft/miniconda3/envs/bokeh-dev/lib/python3.7/threading.py", line 917, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/home/p-himik/soft/miniconda3/envs/bokeh-dev/lib/python3.7/threading.py", line 865, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "docserver.py", line 43, in open_browser
    webbrowser.open("http://localhost:%d/en/latest/index.html" % PORT, new="tab")
  File "/home/p-himik/soft/miniconda3/envs/bokeh-dev/lib/python3.7/webbrowser.py", line 78, in open
    if browser.open(url, new, autoraise):
  File "/home/p-himik/soft/miniconda3/envs/bokeh-dev/lib/python3.7/webbrowser.py", line 251, in open
    "expected 0, 1, or 2, got %s" % new)
webbrowser.Error: Bad 'new' parameter to open(); expected 0, 1, or 2, got tab
```
Not sure where `"tab"` has come from, but it has been there forever.

items.title: [FEATURE] provide an example about moving the legend outside of the main figure
items.body:
### FOLLOW THESE INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY

*ISSUES THAT DO NOT CONTAIN NECESSARY INFORMATION MAY BE CLOSED, IMMEDIATELY*

The issue tracker is NOT the place for general support. For questions and technical assistance, come join the [Bokeh Project Discourse](https://discourse.bokeh.org).

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...]  

I am trying to configure legend of figure from vbar_stack(). I want to move the legend out of the stacked vbar figure so that the legend won't block any content in the main figure area.
The current stacked vbar example "https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/gallery/bar_stacked.html" is using keyword "legend" which is deprecated in bokeh 2.0.2.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.  

I would like a legend manipulation example to be included in the stacked vbar example "https://docs.bokeh.org/en/latest/docs/gallery/bar_stacked.html".
The example should not use deprecated objects.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.  

Deprecated "legend" keyword still works for now.
"add_layout" method was utilized as a work-around to move the legend outside of the main figure.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
